title: Add MR Analytics to usage ping
description:
## Overview
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229045, we added an MR Analytics page.

## Proposal
We need to add views on this page to usage ping, so we're tracking engagement on this feature. Please add:
* A new `i_analytics_*` counter that measures visits on this page
* Add the new ~~Instance Statistics~~ MR Analytics page to our `analytics_unique_visits_for_any_target_monthly` and `analytics_unique_visits_for_any_target` counters, so it's included.

Reference MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37417/


----
Update:
I've traced back what was added and see MR analytics on the group and on the project level, so I'm going to add tracking of unique visits for both pages, with `g_analytics_merge_request` for group and `p_analytics_merge_request` for project respectively. (see [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/236201#note_403323503))

title: Correctly append ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE contents when analyzer is run multiple times
description:
### Problem to solve

While working on [Allow git to use cacert](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/merge_requests/112) I came across the following behaviour with regards to CA Certificate handling:

1. run a secure analyzer `Docker` image locally:

   ```
   docker run -it --rm -v "$PWD:/code" \
     -e ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE="$(cat test.crt)" \
     -e GEMNASIUM_DB_REMOTE_URL=https://gitlab-airgap-test.us-west1-b.c.group-secure-a89fe7.internal/analyzers/gemnasium-db \
     -e SECURE_LOG_LEVEL=debug \
     registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium /bin/sh
   ```

1. execute the analyzer multiple times:

   ```
   / # cd /code
   /code # /analyzer run
   /code # /analyzer run
   ```

1. The analyzer ends up appending the `ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE` contents to the `/etc/ssl/certs/ca-cert-additional-gitlab-bundle.pem` without any newlines, which causes an invalid certificate:

   ```
   /code # cat /etc/ssl/certs/ca-cert-additional-gitlab-bundle.pem

   -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
   MIIEQzCCAyugAwIBAgIUe5OYnWvcwt2MgCpVSUgvFa8E3D0wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
   IPcVVawMK/ChUcbktFylIAu9ohWrJHU5KuDrzhEOyG+0hEFGFnzYfpJSADIHvNNS
   Gtpf/YEZclLD7wHrkhbeIThnU/Z9q270dm15wEGO9MLACEob6DZo
   -----END CERTIFICATE----------BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
   MIIEQzCCAyugAwIBAgIUe5OYnWvcwt2MgCpVSUgvFa8E3D0wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
   IPcVVawMK/ChUcbktFylIAu9ohWrJHU5KuDrzhEOyG+0hEFGFnzYfpJSADIHvNNS
   Gtpf/YEZclLD7wHrkhbeIThnU/Z9q270dm15wEGO9MLACEob6DZo
   -----END CERTIFICATE-----
   ```

   The above certificate file is invalid and will cause other tools that try to use it, such as `git`, to fail. The certificate should instead be formatted as follows, with a newline between each certificate:

   ```
   -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
   MIIEQzCCAyugAwIBAgIUe5OYnWvcwt2MgCpVSUgvFa8E3D0wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
   IPcVVawMK/ChUcbktFylIAu9ohWrJHU5KuDrzhEOyG+0hEFGFnzYfpJSADIHvNNS
   Gtpf/YEZclLD7wHrkhbeIThnU/Z9q270dm15wEGO9MLACEob6DZo
   -----END CERTIFICATE-----
   -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
   MIIEQzCCAyugAwIBAgIUe5OYnWvcwt2MgCpVSUgvFa8E3D0wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
   IPcVVawMK/ChUcbktFylIAu9ohWrJHU5KuDrzhEOyG+0hEFGFnzYfpJSADIHvNNS
   Gtpf/YEZclLD7wHrkhbeIThnU/Z9q270dm15wEGO9MLACEob6DZo
   -----END CERTIFICATE-----
   ```

This behaviour doesn't happen when you specify the `ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE` in a CI variable, which you can see in [the following test](https://gitlab.com/adamcohen/file-write-newline-test/-/jobs/684213601).

It only seems to occur when you pass the certificate file as a commandline Docker environment value such as

```
-e ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE="$(cat test.crt)"
```

It also only occurs when you run the `analyzer` more than once, which should only happen for developers running the analyzer locally to possibly debug issues.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

A user should be able to run the `/analyzer run` command more than once without corrupting the CA Certificate file.

### Proposal

There are a few different possible solutions, we need to figure out the best approach:

1. Figure out the correct way to read the certificate file into the `ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE` environment variable when running Docker from the commandline, because using `-e ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE="$(cat test.crt)"` doesn't work correctly, even when I tried adding newlines into the `test.crt` file
1. Switch to using `fmt.Fprintln(f, b.content)` so that newlines are automatically inserted - I've tested this and it doesn't seem to alter the current behaviour when passing the `ADDITIONAL_CA_CERT_BUNDLE` value as a CI environment variable
1. Update the logic for writing the CA certificate file so it checks to see if the certificate has already been written to the `/etc/ssl/certs/ca-cert-additional-gitlab-bundle.pem` file, and if so, it doesn't append another copy of it
1. Do nothing, but this means that developers testing this locally will only be able to execute the `/analyzer run` command once before it results in an invalid certificate file

### Further details

@dsearles also experienced the problem described in this issue and had the following to say:

> I remember running into a similar error when I was working through changing the behavior to append rather than override. I'm not sure how to solve `1.`, but that would be a nice approach. When I noticed the same behavior, then I switched to `2.`, but noticed that it added an extra newline between the certs and stuck with this approach as it's more common for a single run to happen in an analyzer than multiple runs. From my perspective, `3.` would be ideal, but likely quite difficult to achieve. In the end, I'm open to any of the options above as I'd like to eventually move away from using common for certs in the ~"group::static analysis" analyzers (for more info, see: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218840).

### Implementation plan

Since the git config write in the same package already uses `fmt.Fprintln` to achieve the desired result, it will be consistent to continue to use this: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/master/cacert/bundle.go#L82

- [x] update https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/master/cacert/bundle.go#L54 with `fmt.Fprintln`
   - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/merge_requests/140
- [x] test by building an analyzer with the new version of common and ensuring that running `/analyzer run` multiple times does not corrupt the ca cert in `DefaultBundlePath = "`/etc/ssl/certs/ca-cert-additional-gitlab-bundle.pem`
   - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/jobs/941788552
- [x] update all analyzers that depend on common and release new versions
   - [x] SAST
      - [x] [security-code-scan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan)
         - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan/-/merge_requests/68
         - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan/-/releases/v2.16.1
      - [x] [brakeman](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman)

      - [x] [eslint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint)

      - [x] [spotbugs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs)

      - [x] [gosec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec)

      - [x] [bandit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit)

      - [x] [phpcs-security-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/phpcs-security-audit)

title: Update experiment grouping on subsequent record_experiment_user calls
description:
## The Problem

The way we currently have [the new `experiments` and `experiment_users` tables](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38397/diffs#41af4a6fa5a10c7068559ce21c5188483751d934) set up is likely to cause issues when experiments roll out to more & more users over time.

Here’s the relevant code from the updated `lib/gitlab/experimentation.rb` file:

```ruby
module Gitlab
  module Experimentation
    def record_experiment_user(experiment_key)
      return unless Experimentation.enabled?(experiment_key) && current_user

      ::Experiment.add_user(experiment_key, tracking_group(experiment_key), current_user)
    end
  end
end
```

And here are the related bits from the new `app/models/experiment.rb` file:

```ruby
class Experiment < ApplicationRecord
  has_many :experiment_users

  def self.add_user(name, group_type, user)
    experiment = find_or_create_by(name: name)

    return unless experiment
    return if experiment.experiment_users.where(user: user).exists?

    group_type == ::Gitlab::Experimentation::GROUP_CONTROL ? experiment.add_control_user(user) : experiment.add_experimental_user(user)
  end
end
```

The problem really comes into play on this line from `Experiment.add_user`:

```ruby
return if experiment.experiment_users.where(user: user).exists?
```

What that line is doing is exiting the method early if we’ve already recorded the given user’s `id` for the given experiment name. It does not take into account what the `group_type` was or what it is now.

What will happen is that when we first roll out an experiment we might open it up to 10% of users, and then as we gain insights or gain confidence in the experiment code, we might ramp that up to 25% of users. When we change from 10% to 25% we’ll begin including users in the “experiment” group who were previously in the “control” group. That means we’ve already recorded them in the `experiment_users` database and we’ve already recorded them as being in the “control” group. Even though they are now in the “experiment” group, we’ll see that we’ve already recorded this user `id` for this experiment `name` and we’ll skip recording them again (even though they’re now in the “experiment” `group_type`).

## Proposed Solution

Rather than bailing out on the method altogether, we should run an `update` on the found `experiment_users` row to change the recorded `group_type` from “control” to “experiment”. We should also add a `group_type_updated_at` timestamp column to keep track of when the user’s `group_type` was changed from “control” to “experiment”.

title: Set default for current_value in SAST config UI
description: In the current implementation of SAST config UI, we are reading the default_value from SAST template and current_value from `.gitlab-ci.yml` files. If there is no .gitlab-ci.yml file, the current_value is set to nil. In this issue, we are going to set the current_value to default_value if the `.gitlab-ci.yml` file is missing or a variable is not set in existing `.gitlab-ci.yml`.

title: WebIDE appears to corrupt binary files?
description:
### Summary
We have an alpine repo git repository. E.g. a binary git storage for .apk files. To get files from one branch to the other (master -> release) we cherry-pick the commit that added the file, but part of the cherry-pick merge commit, we also want to remove the 'previous version'. So open the WebIDE, navigate to the old version, and remove the file.

Clicking commit however, already shows that it tried to 'update' the file. This is obviously not desired. What's worse, how was it updated? What was changed? We don't know. But afterwards, sure enough, the file is no longer useable (corrupted).

![image](/uploads/509739ddacfe8b6138618591db921ae5/image.png)

Clicking 'discard' in the right top, after selecting the 'modified' file allows one to undo this change ... but it's unclear _how_ and more importantly _what_ was changed.

Especially the inattentive user may miss this causing all sorts of problems.

title: Render diff rows in parallel mode from the inline diff lines state
description:
* Primary dev: @iamphill 
* Support: @thomasrandolph 

---

## Summary

<!--
Please briefly describe what part of the code base needs to be refactored.
-->

We've assess that the information on the parallel mode is pretty much the same as in inline mode.

This is the logic ~backend is using to generate the parallel response: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/diff/parallel_diff.rb´

This can be derived off the same data structure. This will not only improve the time to switch between inline/parallel but will simplify a lot of the code.

## How?

We've discussed potentially adding a new property:

* `universal_diff_lines` 

Or reusing the highlighted_diff_lines. 

This way we could start adding the improvements done with this refactor in this branch of the state tree.

## Improvements

<!--
Explain the benefits of refactoring this code.
See also https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/index.html#say-why-not-just-what
-->

Simplified state. Easier to update. Easier to add new features (single representation of diff lines instead of one for inline (highlighted_diff_lines) and one for parallel (parallel_diff_lines).

## Risks

<!--
Please list features that can break because of this refactoring and how you intend to solve that.
-->

This distinction is pretty widespread in the app. Side effects will be felt across the entire app.

    > `import { InMemoryCache } from 'apollo-cache-inmemory';`
    > 
    > As you can see here: `spec/frontend/design_management/pages/index_apollo_spec.js`, which would make for a better set of specs against this query 
    > 
    > i.e.
    > 
    > ```
    > 
    > import {
    > vulnerabilityGradesQueryResponse,
    > } from '../mock_data/apollo_mock';
    > import vulnerabilityGradesQuery from '../graphql/group_vulnerability_grades.query.graphql';
    > 
    > mockClient.setRequestHandler(
    >       vulnerabilityGradesQuery,
    >       jest.fn().mockResolvedValue(vulnerabilityGradesQueryResponse),
    >     );
    > ```
    > 
    > But I would be happy to see this as a follow-up as it's a new thing we have only introduced recently :smile:

## Implementation plan

- [ ] Use `createMockClient` and `InMemoryCache` for the tests in [`ee/spec/frontend/security_dashboard/components/first_class_vulnerability_severities_spec.js`](http://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/4f028edce179d212d91417e5dc3168cdd03e4718/ee/spec/frontend/security_dashboard/components/first_class_vulnerability_severities_spec.js#L72-72). They currently use `wrapper.setData()` to set the data that Apollo would've set had it done the GraphQL request, so rather than skip the Apollo call altogether, we should mock out the call instead.

title: Use GraphQL for Vulnerability pages
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

When working on #233825, @mparuszewski and I discussed the need to move to GraphQL for the Vulnerability pages (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38814#note_395629598). This would allow us to use the same routes as are used in the dashboard, and therefore have the same expected behavior. This would be a backend change only, so it should be transparent to users.

### Problem refinement

- [ ] ~backend Utilize the existing GraphQL routes used by the security dashboard to get vulnerability data for Vulnerability pages

title: Rewrite the diff content markup to not use <table>
description:
## Summary

By rewriting the markup of the Diff content to not use a table, we'll be able to go beyond the markup allowed within the `tr` scope. 

This will allow us to build the same UI without the heavy restraints of a table, including using CSS to show and hide visual CTA in the gutters of the lines. (out of scope for this issue).

## Improvements

<!--
Explain the benefits of refactoring this code.
See also https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/index.html#say-why-not-just-what
-->

* More freedom when it comes to markup of each row
* Better performance (need to be checked, but CSS Grid outperforms Flexbox. Table layout is heavy)
* Will enable improvements until then blocked by the table markup.

## Risks

<!--
Please list features that can break because of this refactoring and how you intend to solve that.
-->

This might bring some disruption on how users select the content of the diffs. Beware of the "select text" pattern.

## Involved components

* `app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/inline_diff_view.vue` and descendants

<!--
List files or directories that will be changed by the refactoring.
-->

## Availability and Testing

There are QA tests involving some of the markup to be changed (for example, there's [a QA selector in at least one file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d8af8dd1e0c87233c280aebe45fa6c0432631bab/app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/inline_diff_table_row.vue#L154)), so some QA page objects may need to be updated and `package-and-qa` should be run.

- [ ] Please run `package-and-qa` and consult ~Quality if any tests fail.
